The objective of the fund is to spread the message of participatory watershed development
Promoting sustainable agriculture through conservation of native seeds for the food security –PHP/FRB

The overall goal of the APDMP is to Improve the incomes of 165,000 farm households and strengthen their resilience to drought. This goal will be achieved through the development objective of strengthening the adaptive capacity and productivity of agriculture in the rainfed zones of five districts in southern Andhra Pradesh. These efforts will be supported by a governance framework for water exploitation and irrigation development

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: 1. Conducted 45 days Skill Development Certificate Course for Rural youth for Employability to 39 Rural youth. Out of 39 trainees 36 trainees got placement in 3 companies. 2. Implemented Better Cotton Initiative (BCI)project in 71 villages with 6009 farmers in 5565 Ha. On an average net income of Rs 16710 per Ha was increased and a total amount of Rs 9,29,91,150 farmers income was saved. 3. Established Toll free Help line- Kisan Call centre (1800 425 3377) in KVK and providing timely technical support to the farming community for location specific problems. 4. Created a Whatts APP Group on the name of KARIMNAGAR AGRI GROUP and providing timely technical support to all line department officers. 5. Conducted State level workshop on Promotion of Murrel culture in Telangana State with the support of NFDB 6. Produced746quintal s of Batukamma ( JGL-18047) and 230 quintals of Telangana Sona ( RNR 15048) paddy seed and provided to 3904 farmers of 5 districts 7. Produced 200780 no. of Vegetable seedlings and provided to 71 farmers of 3 districts 8. Conducted Kharif & Rabi Kisan sammelan, Jai Kisan Jai Vigyan, World Soil Health day and farmers fair on PMFBY at KVK as per ICAR guidelines. 9. Procured Mobile Soil testing Kit and analyzed 1315 no. of soil samples and provided soil health cards to farmers. 10. Conducted RAWEP to final year B.Sc(Agri) students of Loyola Academy of Degree and PG College, secunderabad. 11. Stem application in Cotton is demonstrated in 165 villages,2310 farmers fields and area covered in 1420ha and cost of cultivation is reduced 2850Rs/ha 12. Yellow sticky traps installation in different crops for sucking pest management in 96 villages,1994 farmers fields and area covered in 846ha and cost of cultivation is reduced 2430Rs/ha. 13. Pesticide spray precautionary wearing dress (at the time of chemical spray protecting from the chemicals) is supplied to 292 farmers. 14. Bio fungicide Trichoderma viridi is supplied to 122 farmers for wilt management in different crops through soil application. 15. Out of 61 rural Youth (31 members from Tailoring & 30 members from Beauty parlor management) 38members were self employed and earning monthly income by giving their works to public. The programme has been completed with financial support of NABARD, Karimnagar. 16. Five new fish farms site locations were identified for individual fish farm development 17. Eight captive nursery ponds developed for fish fingerlings production for self stocking 18. Supplied 135000 nos quality advanced fish fingerlings to 21 Fishermen cooperative Society tanks ( FCS tanks) 19. Supplied 2630 one month old giriraja chicks and 17 Nellore breed rams to 152 farmers

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: GUTS has been organized by few persons to design develop and verify through implementation some innovative alternative paradigms for providing the energy and other infrastructure services to the poor and importantly to disseminate the new paradigm to achieve expected impact in the society. It is focusing on designing and deploying innovative clean energy devices to replace or supplement the lighting, cooking drinking water purification now being done by the fossil fuel using devices, which leave a large carbon foot print and affect the local and global sustained well-being. Even though the household in rural India are poor and the per household contribution GHG emission is somewhat small compared to urban households, the cumulative emission from the rural households is a significant fraction of the total emission in India. A clear understanding of the nexus between the emissions in rural household due to use of kerosene for lighting and traditional fuel for cooking, the GHG emission produced and the global warming and consequential climate change impact will alone lead to sustained efforts towards the adoption of the energy efficient and renewable forms of energy. Our focus on propagation of the adverse impacts of carbon emission from poor households and assure them to provide technical and related trainings to the youth, for promoting energy efficient and renewable energy. Imparting Training in Solar Technology would help in creating large number of â€œBare Foot Solar Engineersâ€ in the rural villages who not only attends to maintenance of solar equipment but also earn income ranging from Rs.4000 to 5000 per month. Our experience in Ananthapur District of Andhra Pradesh where we have installed about 7000 home lighting systems, these trained youth have been proved to be the â€œTorch Bearersâ€ in the promotion, propagation, demonstration & deployment of various RETâ€™s. Imparting 3 months training in solar energy will give further impetus in creating more Green employment opportunities both self employment and absorption as technicians in renowned solar companies. The objectives of alleviation of poverty, reduction of pollution, generation of Green employment and substitute fossil fuel equipment with Solar Energy can be achieved by training number of youth in Solar Technology. GUTS objectives are promotion, propagation, demonstration and deployment of various RETâ€™s in both Urban and Rural areas. GUTS has been a channel partner to MNRE and completed the solar project entrusted to it under ACE Project of MNRE/UNDP. We have installed about 7000 Home PV lights systems in Ananthapur which is the biggest pilot in the country. As an integral part of the installation of solar equipment in different villages, we have trained number of youth in Solar Technology in all those villages in order to promote Green Employment. These trained technicians are working like â€œBare Foot Solar Engineersâ€ in the villages earning an income of Rs.4000 to 5000 per month besides attending to their own self employment activities. We would also organize standardized & structured solar training programme in association with our knowledge partners like NIRD & PR and ASCI etc.

ngoList.title: HEAL A CHILD FOUNDATION
ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: The foundation started in June 2010, has saved over 720 children in the last Eleven years. Heal-a-Child is one of the few organizations that pay for medical expenses of very poor sick children irrespective of the type of illness. Its primary focus is on newborns and premature babies who need intensive care treatment. Heal-a-Child has partnered with several hospitals across Hyderabad. The children who are supported are directly referred by these hospitals.

sourceOfFunds.purpose: No grant is sanctioned, but registration under sec 80G and 12A is obtained in accordance with provisions of Income tax act, 1961. On the basis of this registration we receive funds which is used for medical treatment of newborns and children whose parents do not have the economic resources to pay for the same. ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Worked on a WASH (Water, Sanitation and Hygiene) project supported by US Consulate meant to educate 500 girls on maintaining cleanliness, hygiene and using toilets responsibly. program included awareness workshops, DIY activity where we taught girls to sew their own cloth pads, Period Quiz and Games and finally handed over a Resource Material to school authorities which becomes a reference guide for girls. We ended the project with distributing cloth pads to girls from United Colors of Benetton

sourceOfFunds.purpose: Period Pride was organized to provide memorable Period Management experience to young girls of an orphanage in the city of Hyderabad. Period Pride focussed on an Awareness Session addressing 350 girls, a talk by a gynaecologist highlighting hygiene practices, nutritional needs and importance of managing Periods safely and hygienically. We organized fun story telling session and distributed hygiene kits to girls which included period essentials for them.

Menstruation forms an integral part of the WASH Project; hence it is important that girls are well trained with appropriate information about managing Menstruation safely and hygienically. They should also be well equipped with unvarying access to products, infrastructure and resources to help them manage their Periods with dignity.

ngoList.title: NARSINGH SWAIN MEMORIAL TRUST
ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: ACHIEVEMENTS OF NARSINGH SWAIN MEMORIAL TRUST The major achievement of the N Swain Memorial Trust is the Aakar [Shape] Asha [Hope] a Super-Specialty hospital for Reconstructive surgery with a built â€“up area of 55,000 sq.ft. in three floors on 2 acres in a strategic location on NH7, the crowded area of once Asiaâ€™s biggest housing localities that is Kukatpally, Hyderabad with an investment of around Rs. 9 crore. The one of its kind project won an award at the 2nd ISB iDiya competition in 2012. Aakar Asha is a referral Centre for Reconstructive Surgery. Apart from Reconstructive Plastic Surgery Orthopedics, Cancer and Pediatric Reconstructive surgeries are done. Specialized services like Oral and Maxillofacial surgery, Dermatology services play a significant role. The allied specialized services that are required for all round requirement of the patient like: Anesthesiologists and Pain management specialists, Physician and Neurologist, Pediatrician, General and Laparoscopic Surgeons and ENT surgeon provide the support services needed for the delightful experience of poor patients during their stay at the Hospital. A state of art Physical Rehab department completes the picture. The hospital has its own 24 x 7 Pharmacy, Diagnostic facilities (clinical pathology, biochemistry and Radiology with Color Doppler), with 3 Operating Theaters [including laminar theater as per NABH guideline], 2 ICUs and Post Op area. It has a capacity of 130 beds with 51 beds in operation of three different categories: General, Sharing and Single rooms other than ICU beds. Besides, the hospital has Dormitory facilities for accommodation of the attendants of the patient during treatment period with in the premises. The kitchen and cafeteria within the premises take care of the patients and their attendantâ€™s dietary needs and provide food for the patientâ€™s attendants. The hospital was built to take care of patient from undivided Andhra Pradesh [presently Telangana and Andhra Pradesh], where the incidence of deformities are high. However, the patient from the neighboring states are been treated with same care and sincerity. The Trust, guided by its objectives, has strived to work for the physically disabled, especially those below poverty line. Activities include creating awareness amongst stakeholders about reconstructive surgery bringing about a transformation in the lives of the physically disabled and helping to identify the beneficiaries; screening camps and reconstructive surgery camps; education and training of doctors and the public. Since 2001, we have conducted more than 30 awareness camps and have distributed literature pertaining to knowledge of physical disability and availability of treatment. No less than 20 free screening camps have been conducted wherein around 1400 persons have been screened for undergoing surgery for physical disability and 900 Physically Disabled persons have undergone reconstructive surgery free of cost since inception of the Trust. 11 Continuing Medical Education programs have been conducted, 8 of which have been the innovative Basic Surgical Skills workshops in which about 250 doctors have been trained hands on. 1 workshop on physiotherapy and a Lifesavers program for first responders have been conducted
